cleaned_text: Vaccine Safety Datalink From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia The Vaccine Safety Datalink Project (VSD) was established in 1990 by the [United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention](/en/United_States_Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention) (CDC) to study the [adverse effects](/en/Adverse_effect) of [vaccines](/en/Vaccine). Four large [health maintenance organizations](/en/Health_maintenance_organization), including [Kaiser Permanente](/en/Kaiser_Permanente), were initially recruited to provide the CDC with medical data on [vaccination](/en/Vaccination) histories, health outcomes, and subject characteristics. The VSD database contains data compiled from [surveillance](/en/Surveillance) on more than seven million people in the United States, including about 500,000 children from birth through age six years (2% of the U.S. population in this age group). [[1]](#cite_note-1) The VSD data-sharing program is now being administered by the [National Center for Health Statistics](/en/National_Center_for_Health_Statistics) Research Data Center. The data sharing guidelines have been revised to include comments from interested groups as well as recommendations from the [Institute of Medicine](/en/Institute_of_Medicine) (IOM). The [Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System](/en/Vaccine_Adverse_Event_Reporting_System) (VAERS), the VSD, and the Clinical Immunization Safety Assessment (CISA) Network are tools by which the CDC and FDA [measure](/en/Measurement) vaccine safety [[2]](#cite_note-CDC_Vaccine_Safety-2) to fulfill their duty as [regulatory agencies](/en/Regulatory_agency) charged with protecting the public.
